q0.bodyText: Is your company's reputation with the public important? (Select the most fitting option)

choices.text: Yes: I want my company to be iconic, to be known for our values and the causes we support
choices.title: Marketing: Purpose-Driven Marketing

choices.text: Yes: I want to be known for being a good employer and an attractive place to work
Yes: I want to be known for developing sustainable products
Not particularly: I care more about planning out my goals and ensuring that my workforce is capable of achieving them
choices.title: Human Resources: Strategic Planning

q1.bodyText: What is the most important factor in developing sustainable products for you? (Select the most fitting option)

choices.text: A happy employee: you can't have sustainable products if your workers suffer
choices.title: Human Resources: Employee Wellbeing

choices.text: Social responsibility: you can't make sustainable products if the neighborhood you are located in suffers because of your operations
choices.title: Marketing

choices.text: The product's design: creating products that are easy to repair/recycle
choices.title: Product Design: Circular-Driven Designs

choices.text: The materials I use in my products: sourcing sustainably ensures I don't damage the environment, or I might even be able to help regenerate it
choices.title: Supply Chain: Sustainable Material Sourcing

q2.bodyText: Out of the following options, what is your priority for your employees?

choices.text: Their wellbeing: I want them to be happy working for me
choices.title: Human Resources: Employee Wellbeing

choices.text: Their potential contributions: I believe in listening to their ideas and giving them a chance at implementation
choices.title: Human Resources: Co-creation of Sustainability

branch_mark_pd_start.bodyText: Does your company have a set of core values, that are enforced within the business and broadcast to the public?

choices.text: Yes
Yes, but not enforced
Yes, but not broadcast
No

mark_pd_1.bodyText: It is important to also enforce the values you talk about towards the public within your company. Else, you might get accused of greenwashing, and that will destroy your positive brand image.

mark_pd_2.bodyText: If you are already adhering to a set of values within the company, those can be a powerful marketing tool towards the public: you might gain customers who share your views simply by telling them about what you value.

mark_pd_3.bodyText: It can be useful to have a set of values to adhere to that you can then tell the public about. Employees might feel more of a sense of purpose with them, and the public might be able to relate to you as a business entity more.

mark_pd_0.bodyText: Is there a social cause or similar that you as a company support?

choices.text: Yes, and it is in line with our values or we do not have values
Yes, but it clashes with our values
No, because we can't find any that adhere to our values
No, for other reasons

mark_pd_5.bodyText: It might be worth to either change your values to align better with the cause you support, or to change the cause itself. The goal is to present a unified front to your target audience, not to confuse them.

mark_pd_5.5.bodyText: It can be beneficial to your image to align yourself with a social cause, but if there are none, you might want to consider creating one based on your values. You might be able to ask your employees for ideas if you don't have any (see also the HR: Co-creation branch)

mark_pd_6.bodyText: Finding a social cause to support will make your customer like your brand more. It might also give your employees more of a sense of purpose, to feel that they're supporting something outside of the company with their work there.

mark_pd_4.bodyText: When marketing products, what does your company focus on?

choices.text: Showcase the qualities of the product, e.g. say it is cheaper than the competition
Present the company's values and causes that it supports, show what will be done with profits made
Market towards a certain target audience or lifestyle, e.g. show an athletic person using your product to perform better

mark_pd_7.bodyText: Your marketing approach is focused on making people want a product for the sake of having the product. With younger generations, this approach will work less and less effectively. Consider switching to a more socially aware branding strategy.

branch_hr_ew_1.bodyText: What is the place of an employee in your company?

choices.text: To work for me - I already have a very defined vision of what I want to do
To help build this company with me - I prefer a more horizontal management style and want their input

branch_hr_ew_1.1.bodyText: Employees have increased productivity if they feel like they have a say in the goings-on of their place of work. Think: are there any ways in which you could use their input/expertise?

branch_hr_ew_2.bodyText: Does your company have an explicitly stated purpose outside of making profit?

choices.text: No, that is our main and only focus
Yes, to provide customers with our products
Yes, we are committed to a cause that does not directly benefit us to support

branch_hr_ew_3.bodyText: How many hours per week do your employees work on average?

choices.text: A normal 40 hour work week
A reduced work week
They work flexible hours that they choose

branch_hr_ew_3.1.bodyText: The 40 hour work week is in the process of being phased out in various countries and industries. With the level of automation we enjoy in society, it is simply no longer necessary, and less work hours per week has been shown to be beneficial to employees' mental health. Consider ways in which you can lower working hour requirements, if possible, and consider hybrid hour structures/letting your employees choose when and how long they work.

branch_hr_ew_3.2.bodyText: Reduced working hours is a big step in the right direction - employees also enjoy being able to choose their own working hours. Investigate whether or not this model is a fit for your business.

branch_hr_ew_4.bodyText: How is the workload (not hours!) distributed amongst your employees?

choices.text: Everyone has a load that is appropriate for their job description and capabilities
Workload is difficult to distribute equally, some employees have more work than others, but are compensated equally
Unsure
Workload is difficult to distribute equally, employees do not get different wages based on their workload

branch_hr_ew_4.1.bodyText: Compensating employees differently based on workloads is logically correct, though it is a difficult system to balance: ensure that the balance is never off, that other employees do not get jealous, that the extra workload is taken on because the employee is capable and does not just need cash, ensuring that employees with extra load do not experience excessive stress because of it...

branch_hr_ew_4.2.bodyText: It can be that sometimes, workload is impossible to distribute equally. In this case, look into hiring employees for differing amounts of hours, having them on-call, or compensating them for their extra effort. Though, it is a difficult system to balance, and your priority should be to ensure that no employee is overly stressed by their workload.

choices.text: In the office/factory, because we prefer everyone to be together when they work for maximum productivity
In the office/factory, because our work cannot be done from home
Hybrid options: employees can choose to work from home or the office on some days

branch_hr_ew_5.1.bodyText: Employees have been shown to prefer hybrid or even fully work-from-home options, as it increases their independence, or they may have a family situation. Look into whether this is possible for your situation, which infrastructure to adapt...

branch_hr_ew_6.bodyText: What happens if something happens to an employee that (temporarily) diminishes their capability to work?

choices.text: Nothing changes, we don't have that flexibility
We have managers trained to handle these situations case-by-case and the resources to facilitate solutions they come up with
Employees have sufficient time off available to deal with events in their own time

branch_hr_ew_6.1.bodyText: It may be worth looking into training your management to handle employee situations nonetheless, as research shows that even just having this option improves employee morale.

branch_hr_ew_6.2.bodyText: Giving employees sufficient time off is a step in the good direction, though having systems in place and managers trained explicitly to deal with individual situations can improve employee morale and your ability to handle these situations.

branch_hr_sp_start.bodyText: Are you aware of the current knowledge and skill levels of your workforce?

choices.text: Yes.
No.

branch_hr_sp_1.1.bodyText: You should be aware of what your employees are and are not capable of, both to avoid overloading them with work they cannot do and to adequately estimate progress towards your goals as a company.

branch_hr_sp_2.bodyText: Are you aware of which skills, employees and resources you need for your goals?

choices.text: Yes.
No.

branch_hr_sp_2.1.bodyText: You should be aware of what it will take to reach your goals. To orient yourself in the problem you want to solve, you must know what it consists of.

branch_hr_sp_3.bodyText: Are the skills of your employees and the requirements for your goals a good match?

choices.text: I don't know: I need to investigate either/both of these further.
Yes.
No: my employees are more skilled than my goals require.
No: my goals require more skilled employees.

branch_hr_sp_3.1.bodyText: Having more human skill in your arsenal than you require can be good news! You can be more ambitious with your goals, or downsize your workforce if you must.

branch_hr_sp_3.2.bodyText: If your goals are too ambitious for your current workforce to achieve, either consider lowering them or work to expand your workforce and their skills to fit your needs. Recruit, (re)train, organize workshops and skill development labs, or outsource work.
